properties.Description: Alta Lake State Park is a 174-acre camping park where the mountainous pine forests meet the desert.

properties.ADA_FeatureList: Campground, fishing pier, picnic area, restroom
properties.Description: Battle Ground Lake State Park is a camping park with 275 acres of beautiful, forested land in the foothills of the Cascade Mountains.

properties.ADA_FeatureList: Cabin, camping, kitchen shelter, picnic sites, restroom
properties.Description: Bay View State Park is a 66-acre camping park with 1,285-feet of saltwater shoreline on Padilla Bay.

Beacon Rock State Park is a 4,464-acre, year-round camping park with historic significance dating back hundreds of years. Located in the heart of the Columbia River Gorge National Scenic Area, Beacon Rock is the core of an ancient volcano.

properties.ADA_FeatureList: Cabins, campsites, picnic area, restroom, trail
properties.Description: Belfair State Park is a 94-acre, year-round camping park on 3,720 feet of saltwater shoreline at the southern end of Hood Canal in western Washington. It is noted for its saltwater tide flats, wetlands with wind-blown beach grasses and pleasant areas

Birch Bay State Park is a 664-acre camping park with 8,255 feet of saltwater shoreline on Birch Bay and 14,923 feet of freshwater shoreline on Terrell Creek. The park is rich in shellfish resources and offers panoramic views of the Cascade

Bogachiel State Park is a thickly forested 127-acre camping park on the banks of the Bogachiel River. "It isn't the end of the world, but you can see it from there." So goes a popular Northwest saying about this vicinity.
Bottle Beach State Park is a 64-acre, day-use park with 6,000 feet of shoreline on Grays Harbor. The open tide flats are the park's most significant feature.
Bridgeport State Park is a 622-acre camping park with 7,500 feet of freshwater shoreline on Rufus Woods Lake. The park provides 18 acres of lawn and some shade in the midst of a desert terrain.

Bridle Trails State Park is a 489-acre day-use park with 28 miles of trails that welcomes equestrians, hikers and visitors.The park is known as one of the top equestrian parks west of the Mississippi; it does not, however, offer horse rentals.
Cama Beach Historical State Park is set in a spectacular, 486-acre waterfront location against a forested backdrop.
Camano Island State Park is a 244-acre camping park with 6,700 feet of rocky shoreline and beach. The park provides sweeping views of Puget Sound, the Olympic Mountains and Mount Rainier.

properties.ADA_FeatureList: Campsites, interpretive center, restroom, trail, yurts
properties.Description: Cape Disappointment State Park is a 2,023-acre camping park on the Long Beach Peninsula, fronted by the Pacific Ocean.

Columbia Hills Historical State Park is a 3,637-acre camping park with shoreline on the Columbia River. Horsethief Butte dominates the skyline like an ancient castle. Horsethief Lake is about 90 acres in size, an impoundment of the Columbia River.
Columbia Plateau State Park Trail is a 3,876-acre day-use park that occupies 130 miles of historic rail line from Cheney to Pasco.
Conconully State Park is an 97-acre camping park with 5,400 feet of freshwater shoreline in north central Washington.
Crawford State Park Heritage Site is a 40-acre, forested day-use park featuring Gardner Cave, a unique and tour-worthy cavern.
Curlew Lake State Park is an 87-acre camping park, 8 miles from the charming gold rush town of Republic.
Daroga State Park is a 127-acre camping park with 1.5 miles of Columbia River shoreline on the elevated edge of the desert scablands
Dash Point State Park is situated on Puget Sound in Western Washington and is a popular destination for water recreation. This 461-acre camping park features 3,301 feet of saltwater shoreline.
Deception Pass State Park is a 3854-acre marine and camping park with 77,000 feet of saltwater shoreline, and 33,900 feet of freshwater shoreline on three lakes.
Dosewallips State Park is a 1,064-acre, year-round camping park with 5 miles of shoreline on Hood Canal and the Dosewallips River. All camp areas are grassy and located in scenic, rustic settings.
Federation Forest State Park is a 574-acre, day-use natural area. The park features five distinct ecosystems within a radius of just one mile.
Fields Spring State Park is an 826-acre, forested camping park in the Blue mountains of southeastern Washington. The park is open year round.
Flaming Geyser State Park is a 503-acre day-use park with more than three miles of freshwater shoreline on the Green River. The park's most unique feature is its geysers, methane seeps.
Fort Casey Historical State Park is a 999-acre marine camping park with a lighthouse and sweeping views of Admiralty Inlet and the Strait of Juan de Fuca
Fort Columbia Historical State Park is a 618-acre day-use historical park located at the Chinook Point National Historic Landmark and along 6,400 feet of freshwater shoreline on the Columbia River
Fort Ebey State Park, a 651-acre camping park on Whidbey Island, was originally built as a coastal defense fort in World War II.

Fort Flagler Historical State Park is a 1,469-acre marine camping park surrounded on three sides by 19,100 feet of saltwater shoreline. The park rests on a high bluff overlooking Puget Sound, with views of the Olympic and Cascade mountains.

Fort Simcoe Historical State Park is a 196-acre, day-use heritage site and is primarily a historic preservation effort. Due to its historic significance, Fort Simcoe was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in June 1974.

properties.ADA_FeatureList: Campground, meeting spaces, restroom,trail, vacation houses
properties.Description: Fort Worden Historical State Park is a 432-acre multi-use park with over two miles of saltwater shoreline and a wide variety of services and facilities. The park rests on a high bluff overlooking Puget Sound.

Ginkgo Petrified Forest State Park is a 7,124-acre park with year-round camping at Wanapum Recreational Area. The park features 27,000 feet of freshwater shoreline on the Wanapum Reservoir on the Columbia River.
Grayland Beach State Park is a 581-acre, year-round, marine camping park with 7,449 feet of spectacular ocean frontage, just south of the Town of Grayland.

Ike Kinswa State Park is a 421-acre camping park with 46,000 feet of freshwater shoreline on the north side of Mayfield Lake. The park provides good fishing, recreational boating, and opportunities for swimming and children's play.
Illahee State Park is a 86-acre marine camping park with 1,785 feet of saltwater frontage on Port Orchard Bay. The park has ample parking, facilities and access to water.
Jackon House State Park Heritage Site is a 1.4-acre day-use park in Chehalis on the Jackson Highway. It was one of the first two properties to be accepted as a state park in November 1915.
Jarrell Cove State Park is a 67-acre, marine camping park with 3,500 feet of saltwater shoreline in the northwest portion of Harstine Island in South Puget Sound.

Joemma Beach State Park is a 106-acre marine camping park with 3,000 feet of saltwater frontage on southeast Key Peninsula. Aside from the natural beauty of park and surroundings, the area is an excellent place for fishing, boating and crabbing.

Accessible only by boat, Jones Island Marine State park is a 188-acre marine camping park with 25,000 feet of saltwater shoreline on the San Juan channel. The park provides mooring buoys on two coves, an ADA dock and trail, a Cascadia Marine Trail campsite and 24 primitive campsites.
Kanaskat-Palmer State Park is a 541-acre camping park on a small, low plateau in a natural forest setting. The park has 2 miles of shoreline on the Green River.
Kitsap Memorial State Park is a 62-acre camping park with 1,797 feet of saltwater shoreline and facilities for group and individual recreation, weddings and overnight stays.
Lake Chelan State Park is a 139-acre camping park on the forested south shore of Lake Chelan. The park has 6,000 feet of shoreline, lakeside views and expansive lawns for strolling and playing.
Lake Easton State Park is a forested, 697-acre, year-round camping park with 24,000 feet of freshwater access on the shores of Lake Easton in the Cascade Mountain foothills.

Lake Sammamish State Park is a 531-acre, day-use park with 6,858 feet of waterfront on Lake Sammamish. The area around the lake carries cultural significance as a gathering place for at least four Native American tribes.
Lake Sylvia State Park is a quiet, 252-acre camping park with 15,000 feet of freshwater shoreline. The park is an old logging camp in a wooded area halfway between Olympia and the Pacific Coast.
Lake Wenatchee State Park is a 492-acre camping park with 12,623 feet of waterfront on glacier-fed Lake Wenatchee and the Wenatchee River.

Larrabee State Park is a 2,748-acre camping park with 8,100 feet of saltwater shoreline on Samish Bay near Bellingham in northwest Washington. The park features two freshwater lakes, coves and tidelands.
Leadbetter Point State Park is a 1,732-acre natural area open for day use. The park features beach frontage on the Pacific Ocean and Willapa Bay.
Lewis and Clark State Park is a 616-acre camping park situated in one of the last major stands of old-growth forest in the state.
Lime Kiln Point is a 41-acre day-use park set on the west side of San Juan Island. The park is considered one of the best places in the world to view whales from a land-based facility.
Lincoln Rock State Park is an 86-acre camping park on the east side of Lake Entiat, created by Rocky Reach Dam blocking the flow of the Columbia River north of Wenatchee.
Lyons Ferry is a 168-acre day-use park with more than 52,000 feet of shoreline at the confluence of the Snake and Palouse rivers.
Manchester State Park is a 128-acre camping park with 3,400 feet of saltwater shoreline on Rich Passage in Puget Sound. Nestled in woods of fir and maple, Bainbridge Island is visible from the beach.
Maryhill State Park is a 81-acre camping park with 4,700 feet of waterfront on the Columbia River in Klickitat County.
Millersylvania State Park is an 903-acre camping park with 3,300 feet of freshwater shoreline on Deep Lake.
Moran State Park is a 5,424-acre camping park with five freshwater lakes and over 30 miles of hiking trails.

Mount Spokane State Park is a 12,293-acre camping park in the Selkirk Mountains with 100 miles of trails and panoramic views from the summit of 5,883-foot Mount Spokane. In winter, the park receives 300 inches of snow.
Ocean City State Park is a year-round, 257-acre camping park, featuring ocean beach, dunes and dense thickets of shore pine.

Olallie State Park is a 2,329-acre day-use park east of Seattle. The park offers 6 miles of moderate hiking trails, excellent fishing, interesting cliffs, local rock climbing opportunities and access to the long distance, mixed-use Palouse to Cascades State Park Trail.
Olmstead Place Historical State Park is a 221-acre day-use park. The park hosts tours and school field trips. Pioneer artifacts are plentiful in the park.
Pacific Beach State Park is a 17-acre camping park with 2,300 feet of ocean shoreline. The beach provides a variety of wonders, from dramatic surf to beach exploration.

properties.ADA_FeatureList: Campsite, path, picnic area, restroom, trail
properties.Description: Palouse Falls State Park is a 94-acre camping park with a unique geology and history. The park offers a dramatic view of one of the state's most beautiful waterfalls.

Palouse to Cascades State Park Trail is a The 4,956-acre, 212-mile camping park. From the densely forested Cascades to the scablands carved by the Ice Age floods, this park gives hikers, cyclists and, in some places, equestrians a taste of Washington’s diversity.
Paradise Point State Park is an 101-acre camping park with 6,180 feet of freshwater shoreline, immediately east of the interstate.

Pearrygin Lake State Park is a 1,186-acre camping park in the Methow Valley of north central Washington. The park features expansive green lawns leading to 11,000 feet of waterfront on Pearrygin Lake.
Penrose Point State Park is a richly forested, 237-acre marine and camping park on the shores of Puget Sound. The park has nearly 2 miles of saltwater frontage on Mayo Cove and Carr Inlet.
Potholes State Park is a 773-acre camping park with 6,000 feet of freshwater shoreline on O'Sullivan Reservoir.

Potlatch State Park is a 84-acre camping park with 5,700 feet of saltwater shoreline on Hood Canal. The park's beautiful grounds are home to a variety of activities, from interpretive programs for kids to boating and shellfish harvesting.
Rasar State Park is a 180-acre camping park with 4,000 feet of freshwater shoreline on the Skagit River.
Riverside State Park is a 11,162-acre camping park along the Spokane and Little Spokane rivers in eastern Washington.
Rockport State Park is a 632-acre day-use park in an ancient forest. The park provides an extraordinary example of old-growth forest.
Sacajawea Historical State Park is a 267-acre day-use park at the confluence of the Snake and Columbia rivers.
Saint Edward State Park is a 326-acre day-use park with 3,000 feet of freshwater shoreline on Lake Washington.
Saltwater State Park is a 137-acre camping park featuring 1,445 feet of saltwater shoreline on Puget Sound, halfway between the cities of Tacoma and Seattle.
Schafer State Park is a 113-acre camping park on the Satsop River, midway between Olympia and the Pacific Ocean.

properties.ADA_FeatureList: Campsites, interpretive center, restroom, showers, trail
properties.Description: Seaquest State Park is a 505-acre, year-round camping park near Mount St. Helens. The beautifully forested park, with large secondary old-growth trees, is situated off Spirit Lake Highway across from Silver Lake and the Mt. St. Helens Visitor Center.
Sequim Bay State Park is a year-round, 92-acre marine camping park with 4,909 feet of saltwater coast in the Sequim rain shadow, just inside Puget Sound on the Olympic Peninsula.
South Whidbey State Park is a 381-acre camping park with 4,500 feet of saltwater shoreline on Admiralty Inlet.
Spencer Spit State Park is a 200-acre marine and camping park on Lopez Island in the Strait of Juan de Fuca. The park has a reputation for excellent crabbing, clamming and car-top boating.
The 40-mile, 526-acre Spokane River Centennial State Park Trail winds through eastern Washington from Nine Mile Recreation Area on Lake Spokane to the Idaho border.
Squak Mountain State Park is a 1,591-acre day-use park just outside of Issaquah and a short 15-minute drive from Seattle.

properties.ADA_FeatureList: Campsites, fishing pier, restroom, showers, trail
properties.Description: Steamboat Rock State Park is a 5,043-acre camping park with 50,000 feet of freshwater shoreline at the north end of Banks Lake.
Steptoe Battlefield State Park Heritage Site is a 3-acre day-use park in Rosalia, in the heart of eastern Washington.
Steptoe Butte is a 168-acre day-use park situated high above the Palouse Hills on the eastern edge of Washington, .
Sun Lakes-Dry Falls State Park is a 3,774-acre camping park with 73,640 feet of freshwater shoreline at the foot of Dry Falls.
Tolmie State Park is a 154-acre, marine day-use park with 1,800 feet of saltwater shoreline on Puget Sound.
Twanoh State Park is a 188-acre, marine camping park with 3,167 feet of saltwater shoreline on Hood Canal in South Puget Sound. It features one of the warmest saltwater beaches in Washington state.
Twenty-Five Mile Creek State Park is a 232-acre inland waters camping park on the forested south shore of Lake Chelan.
Twin Harbors State Park is a 225-acre camping park on the Pacific coast, 4 miles south of Westhaven.

Wallace Falls State Park is a 1,380-acre camping park with shoreline on the Wallace River, Wallace Lake, Jay Lake and Shaw Lake. Located on the west side of the Cascades, the park features a 265-foot waterfall, old-growth coniferous forests and fast-moving rivers and streams.
Wenatchee Confluence State Park is a 194-acre, year-round camping park at the confluence of the Wenatchee and Columbia rivers.
Westport Light State Park is a 560-acre day-use park on the shore of the Pacific Ocean. The Westport Lighthouse, for which the park was named, stands on adjacent Coast Guard property.

properties.ADA_FeatureList: Campsites, picnic area, restroom, showers, trail
properties.Description: Yakima Sportsman State Park is a 266-acre camping park and is on the floodplain of the Yakima River. The park is an irrigated green zone in an otherwise desert area and has a variety of deciduous trees that shade camping and picnic areas.
Trailhead on the Willapa Hills Trail
Trailhead on the Willapa Hills Trail
Trailhead on the Willapa Hills Trail
